property.name: text
property.value:
Top level model of a data transmitter and a receiver component, which communicate via a dedicated communication channel assigned by a service provider. The transmitter and receiver are agnostic to the means of communication being used to transmit packets.
The service channel is modeled as a hidden markov model with 3 states that correspond to three means of communication with different latency characteristics.
The objective of the anomaly detector on the receiver side is to track the communication latency in the received packages ( clocks are assumed to be perfectly synchronized for this demo, so that the latency is known exactly) to determine if the underlying communication channel is a high latency channel. This classification problem may be used to raise flags if the anomaly detector "claims" that the channel is not a standard-latency one and may request reassignment from the service provider.

property.name: text
property.value: Look inside this actor for the hidden markov model estimator/classifier actors

property.name: text
property.value: Use every fourth sequence as training data and every other data sequence as test/classify data

property.name: text
property.value:
The train and test ports provide arrays of observations to the HMMGaussianEstimator, which learns the model, and the HMMGaussianClassifier, which classifies the observations.
HMMGaussianEstimator implements the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm on a Hidden Markov Model (HMM), initialized with starting guesses provided as parameters.
HMMGaussianClassifier accepts parameter estimates for the assumed HMM and performs Maximum-Likelihood classification of observations to the possible hidden states.
The rest of the model constructs the displays.

property.name: text
property.value: compute success ratio of the algorithm by comparing classified labels to the actual labels

property.name: text
property.value: Observer that classifies the communication technology based on noisy observations of the latency.

property.name: text
property.value:
The communication channel model as a Composite QM. Communication delay evolves according to a Hidden Markov Model with Rician emission probabilities.
The modal model generates a latency value, drawn from the corresponding rician distribution at each state, which is consequently used as the "delay" value that is used to delay the particular packet by the produced delay amount.
The "label" of each data point indicates which communication state was used for the transmission of the packet, and for this particular three state communication scheme, takes an integer value in {0,1,2}. For this particular setting: Label 0 : Low Latency service link ( WiFi) Label 1 : Higher Latency service link (GSM) Label 2 : Anomalous link with high latency
Note that this model allows packets to be received in arbitrary order by the receiver.
